commit.message:
Intelligently guess correct line endings

SMTP specifies \r\n for line endings, but sendmail is not actually an
SMTP transaction. While not clearly documented (that I could find),
sendmail being a unix command-line application it likely follows the
convention of using the system's native line-breaks (\r\n on Windows, \n
on Linux, *BSD, etc)

However, naively using the native line endings could result in mixed
use, especially when debugging issues where you're manually piping in
input.

To deal with this, adopt a similar behavior of postfix uses, but basing
the decision of what line ending to use off of the line ending used on
the first line of input.

Intelligently guess correct line endings

SMTP specifies \r\n for line endings, but sendmail is not actually an
SMTP transaction. While not clearly documented (that I could find),
sendmail being a unix command-line application it likely follows the
convention of using the system's native line-breaks (\r\n on Windows, \n
on Linux, *BSD, etc)

However, naively using the native line endings could result in mixed
use, especially when debugging issues where you're manually piping in
input.

To deal with this, adopt a similar behavior of postfix uses, but basing
the decision of what line ending to use off of the line ending used on
the first line of input.

commit.message:
Prevent insertion of additional linebreak in message body

The use of bufio.Scanner meant that linebreaks were handled as part of
the scanner internals. By always appending a linebreak after each call
to scanner.Scan(), it could happen that the final chunk of our input
stream did not end with a newline, causing us to add one incorrectly.

As a result of this, the original email message was incorrectly modified
resulting in, for example, DKIM signatures becoming invalid.

By replacing the scanner with the slightly more low-level bufio.Reader,
we preserve linebreaks in the input we are handling. This means we don't
unconditionally add a linebreak ourselves, avoiding the problem
altogether.

Fixes #5, closes #6

Prevent insertion of additional linebreak in message body

The use of bufio.Scanner meant that linebreaks were handled as part of
the scanner internals. By always appending a linebreak after each call
to scanner.Scan(), it could happen that the final chunk of our input
stream did not end with a newline, causing us to add one incorrectly.

As a result of this, the original email message was incorrectly modified
resulting in, for example, DKIM signatures becoming invalid.

By replacing the scanner with the slightly more low-level bufio.Reader,
we preserve linebreaks in the input we are handling. This means we don't
unconditionally add a linebreak ourselves, avoiding the problem
altogether.

Fixes #5, closes #6

commit.message:
Don't treat "." as end of message

Sendmail, by default, mimics the SMTP protocol in this regard. `-i`
inhibits this.
